text: Durbin: Affordable health care at stake with Barrett's nominationNews Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  STATEDurbin: Affordable health care at stake with Barrett’s nominationSteven Speariesspearie@sj-r.comBuff Carmichael of Springfield, a longtime proponent of LGBTQ issues, said the nomination of Amy Coney Barrett to fill the Supreme Court vacancy created by the passing of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg last Friday is concerning on a number of fronts.“(Barrett’s nomination) is going to be a very big challenge to the separation of church and state,” Carmichael said Sunday. “It’s so vital we keep that alive and well and she’s pretty much on record as not having any desire to do that.”Barrett has a record of following Roman Catholic Church teaching “very, very closely and they don’t have a great record with LGBTQ issues,” said Carmichael, a Fifth Street Renaissance/SARA Center board member and former publisher of the Prairie Flame, an LGBTQ newspaper in Springfield.Brigid Leahy, senior director of public policy with Planned Parenthood Illinois Action, said Barrett has been clear in her statements about disagreeing with Roe v. Wade, the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision that affirmed access to safe and legal abortion.“She has been an active and vocal threat to abortion rights and reproductive health care,” said Leahy of Springfield. “She has cited the Planned Parenthood v. Casey decision by the Supreme Court as an example of where the court failed to overrule an erroneous decision, in that she was meaning Roe v. Wade.“She clearly has a record that she believes that issues around abortion need to be reconsidered and she is open to reversing decisions that have been made already.”Leahy said there could be a scenario where Roe v. Wade is left in name only, but the court says “that you have much more latitude in restricting abortion than it has ever said before which in practice would result in abortion not being accessible.”President Donald Trump’s choice of Barrett of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit drew reaction from other officials around Illinois along partisan lines.U.S. Rep. Darin LaHood, R-Peoria, said Barrett’s Midwest common sense and record as a circuit judge “exhibited a deep intellectual understanding of the law and commitment to the Constitution. I hope the Senate acts quickly to confirm her and I have every confidence that Judge Barrett will continue to serve our nation faithfully on the Supreme Court.”U.S. Sen. Tammy Duckworth, D-Ill., called the nomination “a transparent grab for power.”If Republicans insisted on confirming Barrett, Duckworth added, “the Court could roll back women’s reproductive rights, green light more dark money in politics, jeopardize voting rights and civil rights for Black and brown communities and knock down any progress on climate action.”Tim Schneider, chairman of the Illinois Republican Party, called Barrett “a remarkable woman” and urged the Senate to quickly confirm her nomination.“Amy Coney Barrett is brilliant with a jurisprudence faithful to our constitution and American values,” Schneider said. “I can't think of a better person to carry on Ruth Bader Ginsburg's inspiring legal work on behalf of progress and equality for women.”Before becoming a judge in 2017, the New Orleans native was the Diane and M.O. Miller, II Research Chair in Law and Professor of Law at Notre Dame Law School, where her scholarship focused on constitutional and statutory interpretation and the federal courts.Barrett, 48, is a magna cum laude graduate of Rhodes College in Tennessee and a summa cum laude graduate of Notre Dame Law School.Barrett’s confirmation hearings are set to begin Oct. 12.U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin said it was clear that Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Kentucky, wanted to rush Barrett’s nomination through the Senate before the Nov. 3 election and a Nov. 10 Supreme Court hearing on the Affordable Care Act.“What’s at stake with this nomination is the fate of affordable, quality health care and pre-existing conditions protections for millions of Americans,” Durbin said.With Roe v. Wade and Obergefell v. Hodges, that gave couples of the same sex the right to marry, “the genie is out of the bottle,” Carmichael said. “I don’t think there’s enough power on heaven and earth to put it back in, but they can certainly make life for us miserable trying.”The Rev. John Jenkins, president of Notre Dame, said Barrett had an “impressive intellect, character and temperament."She is a person of the utmost integrity who, as a jurist, acts first and foremost in accordance with the law,“ Jenkins said in a statement.Springfield Bishop Thomas John Paprocki, a civil and canon lawyer, has been a member of the adjunct faculty at the University of Notre Dame’s Law School since 2016.“I congratulate my colleague Amy Coney Barrett on her nomination to serve as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court,” Paprocki said in a statement issued by the diocese Monday. “I pray that this confirmation process may go peacefully, respectfully and successfully for her and her family as well as for our nation.”Contact Steven Spearie at 622-1788, sspearie@sj-r.com or twitter.com/stevenspearie.Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Site Map Legals Our Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Terms of Service Privacy Policy Your Privacy ChoicesContact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Advertising Terms and Conditions Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Help Center Subscriber Guide My Print Account Manage Account Give FeedbackSubscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X Instagram eNewspaper ArchivesJobs Cars Homes Classifieds Reviewed.com 10Best LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions© 2024 www.sj-r.com.
